Text: When you specify a folder to your `CLASSPATH`, only folder of classes or resources are expected, in your case it is a jar file so you have to provide the name of the jar too so your `CLASSPATH` variable should rather be set to `/usr/lib/oracle/11.2/client64/lib/ojdbc6.jar:.`

When you specify a folder to your `CLASSPATH`, only folder of classes or resources are expected, in your case it is a jar file so you have to provide the name of the jar too so your `CLASSPATH` variable should rather be set to `/usr/lib/oracle/11.2/client64/lib/ojdbc6.jar:.`.

Starting from Java 6, you can also use wildcard notation to refer to all jar files directly located in a given folder, in your case, your `CLASSPATH` variable could then be `/usr/lib/oracle/11.2/client64/lib/*:.`.

More details about [Setting the class path][1]


  [1]: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/tools/solaris/classpath.html

When you specify a folder to your `CLASSPATH`, only folder of classes or resources are expected. In your case, it is a jar file so you have to provide the name of the jar too which means that your `CLASSPATH` variable should rather be set to `/usr/lib/oracle/11.2/client64/lib/ojdbc6.jar:.`.

Starting from Java 6, you can also use the wildcard notation to refer to all jar files directly located in a given folder, in your case, your `CLASSPATH` variable could then be `/usr/lib/oracle/11.2/client64/lib/*:.`.

More details about [Setting the class path][1]


  [1]: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/tools/solaris/classpath.html
